author: David Maddock
title: Liverpool "will be ready — we want to reach the EFL Cup final" says Jurgen Klopp before Southampton decider
text:
Liverpool "will be ready — we want to reach the EFL Cup final" says Jurgen Klopp before Southampton decider Their poor display in this semi's first leg suggested title-chasing Reds aren't fussed about the competition Share Klopp has been criticised over his Cup line-ups but is adamant he is trying to win (Photo: Man Utd via Getty)   Thank you for subscribing!   
Jurgen Klopp has promised his under-pressure Liverpool side are desperate to set up a showpiece EFL Cup final... even if it didn’t look like it. 
He claims that no one has taken the competition more seriously than the Anfield club, even if the lethargic display from his team in their semi-final first leg at Southampton two weeks ago suggested they didn’t care. 
The Liverpool manager admits his team are at a low ebb after a devastating first home defeat in a year at the weekend, quick seemed to mortally wounded their title hopes. 
Yet he vowed they will pick themselves up and be motivated to over-turn a 1-0 deficit against Saints on Wednesday night – and in all likelihood set up a dream final against Manchester United at Wembley next month. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Klopp faces the press ahead of EFL Cup match with Southampton Share this video Watch Next 
“We reach for the heights but we don’t know in this moment. But it’s not because of motivation or readiness. We will be ready on Wednesday,” he said defiantly. 
“We want to be in the final, which will be really difficult against Man United - probably [the Red Devils take a 2-0 lead to Hull on Thursday for the second leg of the other semi]- but it’s still possible. I don’t even have to say it. 
“We wanted to win the competition last year, when we reached the final [losing to Manchester City on penalties]. Our brain functions well enough to remember this. Of course we want to be part of the final but don’t just want that, we want to go and win it. 
"The first step is to beat Southampton.” 
Klopp has frequently been criticised for his team selections in both the EFL and FA Cups, but he has always argued that he picks a team to win the match in front of them, based on fitness and freshness. Klopp's men are lucky to still be in the tie as the first leg could easily have ended 3-0 (Photo: Reuters) 
It has served him well in cup competitions, with a third final in just 16 months at the club waiting if Liverpool can turn around the single-goal deficit they were fortunate to escape St Mary’s with. 
While some have questioned whether that display – when Southampton could so easily have won 3-0 – shows Klopp’s team doesn’t really care about this competition, he fired back: 
“If you saw us celebrating after the quarter-final, we were really happy to go to the semi-final. For us, we don’t judge this tournament. It’s the earliest possibility in a season [to win silverware] but we don’t care. 
“It looks like they pressed the EFL Cup in between parts of the season, nobody seems to care about it - the Premier League does not care about it, because we play Wednesday night and then have to play Saturday lunchtime [a 12.30pm kickoff at home to Wolves in the FA Cup]. Liverpool can return to Wembley, where they lost last season's EFL Cup final (Photo: Liverpool FC/Getty) 
"But we know how important it all is, and we want to go to the final too. So there is nothing else we can do now, we have to win.” 
Klopp doesn’t see the EFL Cup as a consolation prize either. 
While just about everyone has already handed the title to Chelsea, he is adamant the Premier League is not over... and his side can still have a massive say in the race. 
“We’re still close enough to fight for nearly everything. OK, if Chelsea wins every game then we cannot fight, but for the rest we can,” he added. 
“You can see we have the quality to fight for the Champions League. We are good enough to do this, and then if we are close enough to the top at the end of the season maybe we can fight for even more. 
“Let’s judge it when it’s done and not feel already, 'Oh my God, again’. Who can deal with a run like Chelsea have been on? We played them once and beat them, so we’re not responsible for their position. We did what we could until now.” View gallery 
Klopp could spring a surprise by throwing centre-back Joel Matip straight back into action after he was cleared by FIFA to play following a dispute with Cameroon over his Africa Cup of Nations participation. 
Skipper Jordan Henderson is also available in midfield despite a heel injury, and Klopp will name his strongest line-up to try to set up what would likely be a showpiece final against Man United. LIVERPOOL vs SOUTHAMPTON PROBABLE TEAMS 
Liverpool Karius; Clyne, Lovren, Matip, Milner; Wijnaldum, Henderson, Lallana; Origi, Firmino, Coutinho. 
Southampton Forster; Cedric, Stephens, Yoshida, Bertrand; Romeu, Ward-Prowse, Clasie; Redmond, Rodriguez, Tadic. LIVERPOOL vs SOUTHAMPTON MATCH FACTS 
This is the fifth time Liverpool have gone into a League Cup semi's second leg behind – on the last two occasions they have recovered to reach the final, doing so against Crystal Palace in 2000/01 and Sheffield United in 2002/03. 
Liverpool haven’t lost back to back League Cup matches since 2005, when they were beaten by Chelsea in the February final then suffered a third-round defeat to Crystal Palace in the October . Liverpool have won the League Cup a record eight times, most recently in 2012 (Photo: Getty Images) 
Of their 53 previous home League Cup matches against top-flight opponents, Liverpool have only failed to score in four. 
The Reds last failed to score in back to back League Cup games in August 1979 . 
Southampton are aiming to reach the final of the League Cup for only the second time – in 1978-79 they eliminated Leeds in the semis before losing the final to Nottingham Forest. 
The Reds have won three of their four home League Cup matches against Southampton, most recently a 3-1 victory in November 2002 with goals from Patrik Berger, El Hadji Diouf and Milan Baros . 
Southampton have won their last three away League Cup matches against Premier League opposition, defeating Arsenal (2014/15 and 2016/17) and Stoke (2014/15). But prior to this run, they’d won just two of 27. Southampton have won three League Cup away games in a row at top-flight sides (Photo: Reuters) 
Only Aston Villa (82) and Arsenal (78) have won more home League Cup matches than Liverpool's 75 . 
Six of the last eight teams to win the first leg of the League Cup semi-final at home by a one-goal margin have been eliminated – only Sunderland (2014) and Spurs (2015) have then reached the final.
